questions.text: The following is caused by?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Loa Loa in the eye.

Loa loa filariasis is a skin and eye disease caused by the nematode worm Loa loa. Humans contract this disease through the bite of a deer fly or mango fly, the vectors for Loa loa. The adult Loa loa filarial worm migrates throughout the subcutaneous tissues of humans.

Subconjunctival migration of an adult worm to the eyes can occur frequently, and this is the reason Loa loa is also called the "African eye worm." 

They mature to adult worms in approximately one year, but sometimes up to four years. Adult worms migrate in the subcutaneous tissues at a speed less than 1 cm/min, mating and producing more microfilariae. The adult worms can live up to 17 years in the human host.

Differential diagnosis:

Onchocerciasis: The parasitic infection caused by nematode Onchocerca volvulus.

Ocular onhocerciasis may affect any part of the eyeball and may cause keratitis, iridocyclitis, choroiditis, glaucoma and optic neuritis and cause blindness (commonly known as ‘river blindness’).

Loa loa, on the other hand, mainly involves subcutaneous and subconjunctival tissues.

Onchocerca is usually smaller in size than Loa loa.

The pattern of microfilaraemia in onchocerciasis is opposite to that in Loa loa.

The microfilaria of Loa loa is usually found in day blood sample. It is known to migrate to the skin and other tissues at night, which causes itchiness commonly reported in ‘night guards’ infested with the disease.

The microfilariae of onchocerciasis migrate from tissues to the blood at night, which makes it ideal to take a blood sample at night. Both parasitic infections may coexist in endemic regions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with headache, fever, and vomiting. On examination, you observe the following. He is diagnosed with herpangina. Which group of viruses causes the same?
questions.solution:
The given image shows palatal ulcers in herpangina. It is caused by the coxsackievirus A, a large subgroup of the enteroviruses.

Herpangina or vesicular pharyngitis is characterized by grayish- white papulovesicular lesions on an erythematous base that ulcerate. These are present on:

  • Soft palate
  • Anterior pillars of tonsils
  • Uvula
  • Posterior oropharynx

It is a common clinical manifestation of coxsackievirus A infection in children, but it can also be caused by coxsackievirus B, echoviruses, or enterovirus 71.

Treatment is usually only supportive, as the disease is self-limiting and usually runs its course in less than a week.

questions.text: Which of the following pathogen is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the trophozoite form of Giardia lamblia which is in the shape of tennis racket or “Heart-shaped” or “pyriform shaped”.

It is bilaterally symmetrical and possesses:

  • Nuclei - 1 Pair
  • Flagella - 4 Pairs
  • Blepharoplast/Basal bodies from which flagella arises - 4 Pairs
  • Axostyles running along the midline - 1 Pair
  • Parabasal or median bodies - 2

questions.text: Tuberculin reaction is an example of:
questions.solution:
Tuberculin reaction is an example of type IV hypersensitivity.

In patients who are sensitized to tuberculoprotein due to prior infection or immunization, an intradermal injection of tuberculin leads to the development of an indurated inflammatory reaction after 48-72 hours. In unsensitized individuals, there is no response.

This is an example of delayed hypersensitivity (Type IV).

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: Given below appearance is a feature of yeast phase of which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
Yeast phase of Paracoccidioides brasiliensis occurs in tissues and in cultures at 37oC as large, globose, or oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cells, giving a mariner’s wheel or pilot’s wheel appearance.

Paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM) is a systemic fungal infection caused by the dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis and Paracoccidioides lutzii. This disease predominantly affects individuals in rural areas of Latin America, particularly Brazil, Argentina, Colombia, and Venezuela.

The fungus can then spread through the lymphatic system and bloodstream to other organs. The immune response to the infection involves both cellular and humoral immunity. Granuloma formation is a hallmark of chronic PCM, with macrophages, lymphocytes, and giant cells surrounding the yeast cells. The disease has an insidious onset with pulmonary involvement, leading to a chronic productive cough, dyspnea, and hemoptysis. Mucocutaneous lesions in the mouth, nose, and pharynx are common and may be painful and ulcerative.

Treatment is with amphotericin B or itraconazole.

questions.text: The following slide is given as a spotter in your microbiology practical examination. Identify the following organism.
questions.solution:
The image shows pink non-branching acid-fast bacilli on a blue background. These findings are consistent with the staining characteristics of mycobacteria. The stain used is the Ziehl-Neelsen stain. 

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows Nocardia stained using an acid-fast staining technique. Nocardia is partially acid-fast and appears as branching filaments.

 

Option C: The image given below is of a gram-stained specimen of Actinomyces israelii. A. israelii is non acid-fast

 

Option D: The images below show the staining characteristics of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is stained with Albert's stain which shows the needle appearance.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which of the following pairs is most likely to be associated with biofilm formation?
questions.solution:
Pseudomonas aeruginosa causing lung infection in the case of cystic fibrosis patients is associated with biofilm formation.

This biofilm provides a hypoxic environment and thereby protects it against antimicrobial agents.

The following image shows pyocyanin of P. aeruginosa, the green pigment in left tube cultured on heart infusion soft agar medium. The aerobic bacteria grow only on the surface of the medium (forming whitish biofilm), and water-soluble green pigment diffuses down.

The following image shows P. aeruginosa with fluorescent pigment under UV-light on cetrimide agar-agar.

Cystic fibrosis:

  • It is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder caused by the presence of mutations in both copies of the gene for the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR).
  • Impaired mucociliary clearance or malfunction of antibacterial peptides, increased the availability of bacterial receptors, and reduced ingestion of pathogens by CF cells are the factors involved in chronic lung infections in cystic fibrosis.

E. coli virulence is mediated by pili that extend from the bacterial cell surface and help mediate adherence to host cell surfaces.

questions.text: A thick, yellowish discharge is noted from the eyes of a five-day-old neonate in the step-down ward during rounds. An iodine-stained smear of the exudates is positive for large cytoplasmic inclusions as shown in the image. Which of the following is false about the organism responsible for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a thick yellowish discharge from the eye showing iodine-stained inclusion bodies is suggestive of inclusion conjunctivitis caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. As chlamydia is a bacteria, it possesses both DNA and RNA.

Chlamydiae are obligate intracellular organisms that produce basophilic inclusion bodies. They are filterable like viruses. They are called energy parasites as they lack enzymes for ATP synthesis. They cannot grow on artificial media but can grow on cell lines like McCoy, HeLa, or the yolk sac of the chick embryo.

Chlamydiae occur in two forms, the elementary body and the reticulate body. The extracellular, infective form is called the elementary body. The intracellular, non-infective, growing, and replicative form is called the reticulate body. These are found inside a membrane-bound compartment called the inclusion body which can be visualized within infected epithelial cells by iodine or Giemsa stain. The cell wall of the reticulate body is fragile and pliable, leading to pleomorphism.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is transmitted by the vector shown in the image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandfly. It is the vector for leishmaniasis.

In the sandfly, leishmania occurs in promastigote form with a spindle-shaped body and a single flagellum arising from anterior end.

Note: Sandfly acts as a vector for the following diseases:

  • Kala-azar
  • Oriental sore
  • Sandfly fever
  • Oroya fever

Related Pearl: Sandfly

  • They are also referred to as Phlebotomus.
  • They transmit diseases such as kala-azar (visceral leishmaniasis), Oriental sore, sandfly fever, and Oroya fever.
  • They are generally smaller than mosquitoes and are hairy insects.
  • They like to dwell in cracks and crevices in walls during the daytime. They are active during the night (nocturnal pests).
  • They do not fly for more than 50 yards.
  • They can be controlled by insecticides and also by proper sanitation.

questions.text: A man has relapsing fever, rash and arthralgia a week after he had a rat bite. Which of the following organisms may be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Relapsing fever, rash and arthralgia a week after a rat bite is suggestive of rat bite fever. Causative organisms for rat bite fever are spirillum minus and streptobacillus moniliformis. Both are natural parasites of rodents.

Other options:

  • Acinetobacter: Opportunistic pathogen in human skin. It can cause ventilator associated pneumonia, meningitis.
  • Legionella: Cause legionare’s disease, pontaic fever
  • Eikenella: Normally present in mouth, GIT, Upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: A newborn diagnosed with a hepatoblastoma is planned for liver transplantation. Her father is found to be an HLA match, and he donates part of his liver. What type of transplantation is described here?
questions.solution:
The transplant of an organ/tissue from a father to child is an example of an allograft.

Related Pearl: Types of transplants

Type  Definition
Orthotopic

Organ implanted in the same anatomic location in the recipient as it was in the donor. Diseased organ is removed. Eg: heart, lung, liver, intestine
Heterotopic

Organ implanted in a different anatomic location. Diseased organ is left in place. Eg: Kidney, pancreas
Auxiliary transplantation Partial tissue from the donor is used which acts as temporary support for the recipient's injured organ, which remains in place. Eg: left lobe of liver
Autotransplant  Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same person. 
Allotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs within the same species. 
Xenotransplant Transfer of cells/tissues/organs in a different species.
Isograft Transfer of organ or tissue within genetically identical individuals. Eg: Identical twins

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl presented with fever, increased urinary frequency, and dysuria. The physician suspects a urinary tract infection. What is the most likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common cause of urinary tract infection (UTI) at any age. It accounts for about 90% of the cases in young women who present for the first time.

The symptoms and signs may include:

  • Fever
  • Urinary frequency
  • Dysuria
  • Pyuria
  • Hematuria
  • Flank pain in upper UTI

questions.text: A female patient presented to the OPD with dysuria and frequent micturition. Urinalysis showed pus cells. A culture study yields a gram-negative rod, forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar, and shows swarming on the blood agar plate. What is the likely causative agent implicated here?
questions.solution:
A gram-negative rod, forming non-lactose fermenting colonies on MacConkey's agar with characteristic swarming motility is suggestive of Proteus.

Swarming effect is produced on blood agar which is characterized by expanding rings (waves) of organisms over the surface of the agar. Organisms exhibiting swarming include:

  • Proteus
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Clostridium tetani

Proteus species are Gram-negative, non-capsulated, pleomorphic, motile rods. They are opportunistic pathogens, often causing nosocomial infections, infections in burns, and commonly responsible for urinary tract infections.

Proteus species are urease-positive, non-lactose fermenters. They possess the enzyme phenylalanine deaminase which converts phenylalanine to phenyl pyruvic acid (PPA). This is called the PPA reaction.

Proteus species exhibit swarming on solid media such as blood agar by using their peritrichous flagella. The image below shows the swarming effect.

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by:
questions.solution:
The Reynolds-Braude phenomenon is shown by Candida albicans.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. This is called the Reynold Braude phenomenon.

The image given below shows germ tube formation seen in candida species.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (buds do not separate from parent cells) and true hyphae forms.

Candida appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. On Sabouraud dextrose agar, they appear as off-white pasty colonies. Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

After incubation on CHROMagar for 1–4 days, colonies are seen: Candida albicans colonies appear green, as shown below; Candida glabrata colonies appear dark purple; and Candida parapsilosis colonies have a pinkish hue.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata.  Vaginal mucosal invasion by the organism causes vulvovaginitis, marked by pruritus and vaginal discharge. A white pseudomembranous patchy lesion called thrush can occur on the tongue, lips, or gums.

The image given below shows oral thrush.

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

Mucocutaneous manifestations are managed with topical nystatin or oral ketoconazole.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with fever, joint pains, and headache. Chik sign (image given below) is present on the patient's nose. Which of the following vectors transmits the etiological agent?
questions.solution:
The given case scenario with fever, joint pain, headache, and Chik sign is suggestive of chikungunya which is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquitoes.

Chikungunya presents with sudden onset of fever, crippling joint pain, lymphadenopathy, and conjunctivitis. The fever is typically biphasic with a period of remission after 1–6 days. Nose pigmentation is striking in cases of Chikungunya fever and is termed as Chik sign.

No animal reservoir has been identified.

Note: Although Chikungunya is transmitted by both Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus, A.Aegypti is considered primary vector of transmission for Chikungunya.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents to your clinic with photosensitivity, redness, and watering of the eyes for the last 2 days. She shows you this photo of a swelling in her hand that had arisen 2 weeks back but disappeared in just 3 days. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Photosensitivity, redness, and watering of the eye with the image showing Calabar swelling is suggestive of loiasis caused by Loa loa.

Loa loa is transmitted by the bite of Chrysops species (deerflies). The infective form is the third-stage microfilarial larva. After entry into human skin, it grows into an adult worm and migrates in subcutaneous tissue. Patients present with Calabar swellings, which are temporary foci of inflammation (angioedema and erythema) that appear as Loa loa wanders through the subcutaneous tissues. They are up to 3 cm in size and are also called fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere. Ocular manifestations occur when the worm reaches the subconjunctival tissue during its wanderings. They include granuloma in bulbar conjunctiva, painless edema of the eyelids and proptosis.

The image below shows Calabar swelling.

The image below shows a live, adult Loa loa in the anterior chamber of the eye.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man was brought to you with a history of fever, behavioral changes, and seizures. He is foaming at the mouth and is unable to ingest liquids. The patient was admitted to the ICU, however he died soon after. What is the following finding seen in the patient's post-mortem brain samples known as?
questions.solution:
Fever, neurological symptoms like seizures and altered sensorium, hydrophobia (due to painful muscle contractions during swallowing liquids), and hypersalivation are suggestive of encephalitic rabies. The given image thus represents Negri bodies seen in post-mortem brain samples of patients with rabies. 

Negri bodies are eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons that are composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA. These are commonly observed in the Purkinje cells of the cerebellum and the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus. Their presence is a characteristic pathologic finding in rabies.

The image below shows Negri bodies:

questions.text: Which of the following is also referred to as Dane particle?
questions.solution:
Dane particle refers to Hepatitis B.

Sera from hepatitis B patients when observed under an electron microscope show three types of particles:

  • Spherical particle: 22nm, most abundant, contains only HBsAg.
  • Filamentous or tubular particle: 22nm, contains only HBsAg.
  • A double-walled spherical structure: 42nm diameter, is the complete Hepatitis B virus. It was described by Dane and is called Dane particle.

questions.text: The below given appearance is related to:
questions.solution:
In the given image, the black arrow points towards maltese cross, and yellow arrow points towards the ring form seen in Babesia.

Babesia, a genus of protozoan organisms that includes Babesia microti and Babesia duncani, are responsible for babesiosis. Ixodid ticks are the definitive host. Man is an intermediate host. Sporozoites are the infective form of humans.

The mode of infection is through a tick bite. Occasionally it can also be through blood transfusion.

The majority of the clinical symptoms are predominantly caused by hemolysis of the infected erythrocytes. The illness develops 1-6 weeks after the tick bite. It might be a mild, self-limiting, asymptomatic, or severe sickness that resembles malaria.
Malaise, exhaustion, high-grade fever (38°C to 40.6°C) with chills and sweating, myalgia, arthralgia, a dry cough, and anorexia are symptoms of acute illness.

Complications of acute babesiosis include renal failure, disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and congestive cardiac failure (CCF).

On microscopic examination by Giemsa stain, Babesia trophozoites appear as intraerythrocytic round or pyriform or ring form. The ring form is the most common and it lacks the central hemozoin deposit which differentiates it from P. falciparum. Other distinguishing features are the absence of schizonts and gametocytes and the presence of tetrads/Maltese crosses, which are pathognomonic of B. microti or B. duncani.

Treatment of B. microti infection

  • Mild infection is treated with atovaquone along with azithromycin
  • Severe infections are treated with azithromycin along with atovaquone or clindamycin along with quinine
  • Exchange transfusion is required in patients with high-grade parasitemia (≥10%), severe anaemia, and pulmonary, hepatic, or renal compromise.

Other Babesia infections are treated with a combination of clindamycin and quinine.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of antibiotic susceptibility testing cannot be used to calculate the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug?
questions.solution:
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods.

MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism. Methods to determine MIC include:

  • Tube dilution method
  • Agar dilution method
  • E-test method

World Antimicrobial Awareness Week, Nov 18-24 2022, is a global campaign that is celebrated annually to improve awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance and encourage best practices among the public. The theme for this year is “Preventing Antimicrobial Resistance Together” to encourage the prudent use of antimicrobials and to strengthen preventive measures addressing antimicrobial resistance

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, malaise, and pharyngitis. On examination, splenomegaly was present and lymph nodes were normal. Peripheral smear showed a predominance of lymphocytes. The heterophile antibody test result is negative. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Fever, malaise, pharyngitis, splenomegaly with lymphocytosis suggest infectious mononucleosis. Cytomegalovirus is the most common causative agent of heterophile-negative infectious mononucleosis.

Patients may develop CMV infectious mononucleosis spontaneously or after transfusion of leukocyte-containing blood products. They present with fever, malaise, pharyngitis and splenomegaly. Cervical lymphadenopathy is rare. Some patients develop rubelliform rashes after exposure to ampicillin. Unlike EBV mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies are negative. This condition is less severe than the infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

questions.text: True statement about mutational drug resistance is:

choices.text: Drug combinations can prevent development of resistance

questions.solution:
In a mutational drug resistance drug combinations can prevent development of resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following secretory immunoglobulin is dimeric joined by a J chain?
questions.solution:
Secretory IgA is a dimer, formed by two monomer units joined  together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide known as J-chain.

  • IgA occurs in two forms – Serum IgA and Secretory IgA
  • Serum IgA is a monomer.
  • Secretory IgA is synthesised by plasma cells situated near the mucosal or glandular epithelium. The J chain is also produced by plasma cells.
  • IgA has an important role in providing mucosal immunity.

IgM is a pentamer, consisiting of 5 subunits, which are joined by J-chain.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with HIV presents with lab reports showing: Low albumin, massive proteinuria. Renal ultrasound shows large, echogenic kidneys. Blood pressure is normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
This patient with HIV presents with massive proteinuria and hypoalbuminemia. The most likely cause is HIV-1-associated nephropathy (HIVAN) - A form of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). 

Proteinuria is the hallmark of this disorder. Edema and hypertension are rare. A definitive diagnosis is obtained through renal biopsy.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease?
questions.solution:
The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

  • Aseptic meningitis is associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

Note: Conditions associated with the rash on palms and soles: Secondary syphilis, Hand foot, and mouth disease, Rickettsial feature caused by Rickettsia rickettsiae

questions.text: A 20-year-old male from West Bengal, presents with complaints of recurrent fever with chills for the past 3 months with progressive weakness and abdominal discomfort. On examination he has hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspiration finding is given in the image. Which of the following can be given for the treatment?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of recurrent fever with chills, progressive weakness, and hepatosplenomegaly along with the presence of intracellular organisms within the macrophages is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. It can be treated with sodium stibogluconate. 

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India. For most regions of the endemic regions of the world, pentavalent antimony compounds like sodium stibogluconate are the drug of choice. In India, antimony resistance has been noted and thus Amphotericin B is the drug of choice. Miltefosine is an oral drug that is also approved for treatment of this condition

Kala-azar or visceral leishmaniasis is a protozoal infection mainly affecting the reticuloendothelial system. It is caused by the Leishmania donovani complex which includes L. donovani and L. infantum. These organisms are transmitted by sandflies. When the infected sandfly bites a person, infectious promastigotes are released into the host dermis along with the sandfly's saliva, which potentiates parasite infectivity.

L. donovani exists in 2 forms:

  • Amastigote form- in humans and other mammals
  • Promastigote form- in the sandfly and artificial culture

The amastigote form (as shown in the image below) is also known as the Leishman-Donovan (LD) body. It is an intracellular form found inside macrophages, monocytes, and reticuloendothelial cells. It contains a kinetoplast which consists of a parabasal body and a blepharoplast. Flagellum is absent.

Promastigote form (as shown in the below image) is present in the midgut of the female sandfly. The kinetoplast lies transversely near the anterior end. A single flagellum is seen. It is the infective form of Leishmania donovani for humans.

In India, it is endemic to Bihar, West Bengal, Jharkhand, and Uttar Pradesh. Patients present with high fever, hepatosplenomegaly, weight loss, and emaciation. The skin becomes dry, rough, and darkly pigmented. There is anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia.

Diagnosis:

  • Rapid diagnostic test: rK39 Rapid diagnostic test and Kala azar dipstick test strip.
  • Parasitological diagnosis: Demonstration of LD bodies in buffy coat smear - confirmatory.
  • Aldehyde test of Napier: Widely used for surveillance.
  • Serological tests for diagnosis: Rapid dipstick test, Direct agglutination test, ELISA, Indirect Fluorescent Antibody Test.
  • Leishmania (Montenegro) test: Induration of 5 mm or more is considered positive, usually positive 4-6 weeks after onset in cutaneous leishmaniasis, valuable for distinguishing immune from non-immune subjects and endemicity.

Drugs used in the treatment of visceral leishmaniasis are sodium stibogluconate, miltefosine, and amphotericin. Liposomal amphotericin single dose 10 mg/Kg IV is the first line of treatment in India.  

Other options:  

Option A: Benznidazole is used in the treatment of Chagas disease caused by protozoa Trypanosoma cruzi. 

Option C: Suramin is used in the treatment of African sleeping sickness caused by Trypanosoma brucei. 

Option D: Atovaquone can be used in the treatment of babesiosis and Pneumocystis jiroveci infection.

questions.text: Which of the following Plasmodium spp. has the longest incubation period?
questions.solution:
Plasmodium malariae has the longest incubation period of 28 days.

The incubation period is the interval between the infective mosquito bite and the first appearance of clinical symptoms. The average incubation periods for Plasmodium species are:

  • P. vivax: 8-31 days (14 days)
  • P. falciparum: 8-14 days (12 days)
  • P. ovale: 8-31days (14 days)
  • P. malariae: 18-40 days (28 days)

Note: The pre-patent period is the interval between the entry of the parasites into the host and the time when they first become detectable in blood.

questions.text: Which among the following occupation is a risk factor for this presenting illness?
questions.solution:
The above image shows cutaneous larva migrans. Being a kennel worker is a risk factor for this job as exposure to animal feces is high.

As Larvae are found on sandy beaches, and under dwellings, swimming in natural water bodies would be a risk and not artificial ones like swimming pools. 

CLM is caused by various animal hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma brazilienses), and the parasite is acquired from direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The parasitic infection usually begins with an inflamed papule, often located between the toes, where the hookworm species (e.g., Ancylostoma brazilienses) larvae enter the skin.

Serpentine or linear single-track lines later mark the course of the larvae as they migrate through the epidermis of the trunk and lower extremities.

Ivermectin is the first-line drug for the treatment of cutaneous larva migrans, taken as a single 200 μg/kg oral dose.

questions.text: Transmission assessment survey is carried out for:
questions.solution:
Transmission assessment survey is carried out for filariasis.

Mass Drug Administration is used to reduce infection in the community to levels below a threshold at which mosquitoes are unable to continue spreading the parasites from person to person and thus new infections are prevented.

The transmission assessment survey (TAS) is used to determine when infections have been reduced below target thresholds and Mass Drug Administration can stop. Once MDA has stopped, TAS is used as a surveillance tool to determine that infection levels are sustained below target thresholds.

questions.text: A 23-year-old girl presents with the finding shown below. She has a history of multiple similar episodes in the past and reports that some of her family members have similar complaints. She has no itching. Which of the following is deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
This girl presents with features of hereditary angioneurotic edema, which is due to a deficiency of C1 inhibitor. 

Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder that is more common than complement deficiency states. A deficiency of C1 inhibitor leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein. This increases the production of vasoactive peptides such as bradykinin. It causes episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the gastrointestinal tract. This may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.

Note -

  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - collagen vascular disorders.
  • C5-C8 deficiency - recurrent bacteremia with Neisseria

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated cucumbers the previous day. What is the most likely etiologic organism?
questions.solution:
Fever, headache, abdominal pain, diarrhoea following consumption of refridgerated food is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

Listeria monocytogenes can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), under conditions of low pH and high salt. So it is able to overcome food preservation and safety barriers, making it an important foodborne pathogen. 

Healthy persons exposed to L. monocytogenes in food may develop a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting 1–3 days. This develops after an incubation period of 6–48 hours. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Immunocompromised individuals can develop meningoencephalitis, bacteremia, or focal infections.

The drug of choice is high dose intravenous ampicillin.

questions.text: A middle-aged man residing in a rural area presents with psychosis, ataxia and convulsions. On further inquiry, you find out there is history of similar complaints in the family members who recently consumed food prepared with grains as shown in the image. What is the poisoning is most likely due to?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the presence of dark coloured ergot growing on the wheat as shown in the image are suggestive of ergotism due to Claviceps purpurea

Mycotic poisoning is of two types: 

1. Mycetism: The fungus itself causes toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Claviceps → Ergot poisoning
  • Coprine → Coprine poisoning
  • Inocybe → Muscarine poisoning

2. Mycotoxicosis: Fungal toxins contaminate food and cause toxic effects.

Examples:

  • Aflatoxins: These are a type of mycotoxins produced by Aspergillus species of fungi, such as Aspergillus flavus and Aspergillus parasiticus.
  • Fusarium toxins
  • Citrinin toxin was first isolated from Penicillium citrinum.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man living in the UK is planning to travel to India. His doctor advises him to take the typhoral vaccine. Which of the following days are included in the schedule?
questions.solution:
Days 1, 3, and 5 are included in the schedule of typhoral vaccine, if day 1 is the first dose of the vaccine. In other words, it should be given on alternate days.

Typhoral vaccine is a live oral typhoid vaccine containing a mutated Salmonella typhi Ty21a. This strain lacks the enzyme UDP- galactose- 4 epimerases. It initiates an infection after ingestion, but the strain is self-destructible. Hence does not cause a serious illness.  

The schedule is 3 doses on alternate days, i.e., on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day. The capsules are enteric coated and taken an hour before food. No antibiotic should be taken during the schedule.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presented with painful lesions on one side of his chest. What is the causative organism of the condition shown below?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a painful rash following dermatomal distribution is suggestive of shingles or herpes zoster, caused by the varicella-zoster virus.

It is characterized by a unilateral vesicular dermatomal eruption associated with severe pain. It is more common in old age typically after 50 years of age.

The pathogenesis is mainly due to the reactivation of the latent varicella zoster virus. 

Clinical features include unilateral rash and confined to the area supplied by a single sensory ganglion. The most common sites involved are D3 to L2 dermatomes. It can also involve the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve. Pain and paresthesia can be seen for weeks or months. Other features such as lower motor neuron paralysis and, meningoencephalitis can occur rarely.

Ramsay Hunt syndrome refers to the involvement of the facial nerve. It is characterized by eruptions on the tympanic membrane, external auditory meatus, and ipsilateral facial palsy.

Diagnosis of shingles is mainly a clinical diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: Herpes simplex virus can cause various manifestations. It includes cutaneous lesions on the cheeks, around the mouth/forehead, buttocks, eczema herpeticum, gingivostomatitis, pharyngitis, corneal blindness, encephalitis, and urethritis. Lesions do not follow a dermatomal distribution.

Option C: Cytomegalovirus can cause congenital infection which is characterized by generalized infection, hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, thrombocytopenic purpura, and hemolytic anemia.  In infants, it can cause an inclusion disease when born to mothers infected during pregnancy. It can occur as post-transfusion mononucleosis in children following the transfusion of infected blood. 

Option D: Ebstein Barr virus can cause infectious mononucleosis. It is characterized by fever, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and peripheral smear showing abnormal mononuclear cells. A rash may develop in some patients who are treated with ampicillin.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with high-grade fever, chills, and rigors for the past 3 days.  A peripheral blood smear revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding the diagnostic methods used to detect the condition he is likely suffering from?

choices.text: Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for peripheral smear examination
pLDH antigen test is specific for detection of the causative agent
Acridine orange dye is used in quantitative buffy coat method
Rapid diagnostic tests have lesser sensitivity than microscopy

questions.solution:
High-grade fever, chills and the peripheral smear showing double chromatin ring forms are suggestive of P. falciparum malaria. HRP-2 antigen detection used in rapid diagnostic tests for malaria is specific for P. falciparum. pLDH is positive for all Plasmodium spp. 

Rapid diagnostic tests are based on the detection of antigens using immunochromatographic methods. They are less sensitive than microscopy and also cannot differentiate between species except P. falciparum. The 2 antigens detected are:

  • pLDH (parasite lactate dehydrogenase): Pan-malarial antigen
  • HRP-2 (histidine-rich protein 2): Specific for P.falciparum.

Parasite-F test is a rapid diagnostic test for the detection of HRP-2. The dual antigen test is a rapid diagnostic test for the detection of both pLDH and HRP-2. 

Other diagnostic methods include microscopy of peripheral blood smears, quantitative buffy coat, culture and molecular diagnosis. Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya (JSB) stain is routinely used in India to stain peripheral blood smears. In quantitative buffy coat, a small quantity of blood is centrifuged. The RBCs containing malarial parasites settle just below the buffy coat of leukocytes, on top of the normal RBCs. The tube is precoated with acridine orange dye, which induces fluorescence in the parasites (the dye stains nucleic acids which are absent in mature RBCs). The parasites appear greenish-yellow against a red background.

questions.text: What are the changes in the variable regions of an immunoglobulin known as?
questions.solution:
Changes in the variable regions of heavy and light chains of an immunoglobulin are called an idiotype. 

Other options:

Option B: Isotypes are the changes in the constant regions of the heavy chain of the immunoglobulin. 

Option C: Allotypes refer to multiple alleles that exist for some genes. This leads to subtle amino acid differences that occur in some but not all members of the same species. 

Option D: An epitope is the smallest unit of antigenicity and it is an antigenic determinant.

questions.text: What is the duration of validity of 17D vaccination?
questions.solution:
17D vaccine (yellow fever vaccine) is valid for a lifetime, beginning 10 days after vaccination. According to the amendment in 2016 to International Health Regulations 2005, the validity of the related international certificate of vaccination against yellow fever has been changed from ten (10) years to the lifespan of the person (traveler) vaccinated.

It is a live-attenuated vaccine derived from the 'Asibi strain', administered subcutaneously. Immunity after a single dose is long-lasting and provides lifetime protection. It is thermolabile. Antibodies and memory T cells have been detected up to 60 years after vaccination, which is why it is considered to offer lifelong immunity. 

Vaccination is compulsory for travel to and from endemic areas.In India, 17D is manufactured at the Central Research Institute, Kasauli.

questions.text: Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by ________
questions.solution:
Blueberry muffin syndrome refers to the congenital infection caused by the rubella virus.

The commonest malformations caused by rubella are cardiac defects, cataracts, and deafness, which constitute the classical congenital rubella syndrome. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenic purpura, myocarditis, and bone lesions is referred to as expanded rubella syndrome. The thrombocytopenic purpura present in the babies gave rise to the term blueberry muffin syndrome. 

While the blueberry muffin syndrome is characteristically caused by rubella, the blueberry muffin-like hemorrhagic purpuric eruptions may also be seen in the case of congenital cytomegalovirus infection.

The following image shows blueberry syndrome:

Other options: Maternal varicella occurring close to delivery may cause congenital varicella syndrome in babies in the first 2 weeks of life. This presents as a serious disseminated disease with a risk of encephalitis and pneumonia.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with features mimicking appendicitis. Upon removal, the appendix is found to be grossly and histologically normal. A stool examination revealed motile gram-negative rods with a safety pin appearance. What is the etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
It is a case of pseudo-appendicitis (appendicitis-like syndrome), caused by Yersinia enterocolitica. The picture showing bipolar staining or safety pin appearance is suggestive of Yersinia species on Wayson stain.

Yersinia enterocolitica is a gram-negative bacillus with a safety pin appearance. It causes gastroenteritis or mesenteric lymphadenitis after ingestion of contaminated food or water. 

In young children, it causes a self-limiting diarrheal illness. Patients with HLA-B27 who were infected with Y. enterocolitica develop arthralgia, arthritis, and erythema nodosum. 

Yersinia can be recovered from the stool of infected patients using selective media called CIN (Cefsulodin-Irgasan-Novobiocin) agar incubated at room temperature. Their colonies have a bull's eye appearance with a red center on CIN agar. Yersinia enterocolitica is motile at 25 °C, which differentiates it from Y. pestis which is non-motile.

Treatment for gastroenteritis caused by Y. enterocolitica consists of ciprofloxacin or a third-generation cephalosporin.

Other options : 

Option A: Clostridium difficile is a long slender gram-positive bacillus. It has large spores which are oval and subterminal. It is an opportunistic organism that rarely causes disease and does so only when normal flora is lost. It causes acute colitis with bloody or watery diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi are gram-negative rods that are motile with peritrichous flagella. It causes enteric fever or typhoid fever. 

Option C: Vibrio parahaemolyticus resembles V. cholera in its morphology except that it is capsulated shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. Strains isolated from humans are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar (special high salt blood agar). This is known as the Kanagawa phenomenon. It causes food poisoning associated with marine food intake. Abdominal pain, vomiting diarrhea, and fever are the usual signs.

questions.text: Deficiency of complement components C5-C8 leads to ______

choices.text: Recurrent infections with gram negative cocci
Recurrent swelling of the lips and tongue

questions.solution:
Deficiency of terminal complement components (C5-C8) leads to recurrent infections with gram negative cocci. 

  • C1 inhibitor deficiency - Hereditary angioedema. 
  • C1, C2, C4 deficiency - SLE and other Collagen vascular disorders.
  • C5-C8 deficiency - Recurrent bacteremia with Neisseria. 
  • CD 59 deficiency - Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

Related Pearl: Complement deficiency and associated diseases

Related Pearl: Functions of Complement

  • Inflammation: C3a, C5a, and, to a lesser extent, C4a are called anaphylatoxins.
  • C5a is also a chemotactic agent.
  • Opsonization and phagocytosis: C3b and its cleavage product iC3b (inactive C3b) act as opsonins and promote phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages.
  • Cell lysis

This role of complement is important mainly for the killing of microbes with thin cell walls, such as Neisseria species, and deficiency of the terminal components of complement predisposes to Neisseria infections.

questions.text: All of the following are examples of flavi virus except ___________
questions.solution:
Chikunguniya is not a flavi virus. It is an alpha virus belonging to toga viridae family.

Yellow fever, dengue, and zika virus are examples of flavi viruses.

questions.text: The smallest unit of antigenicity is called
questions.solution:
The smallest unit of antigenicity is called the epitope or antigenic determinant. An epitope is defined as a small area present on the antigen that is capable of sensitizing immunocytes and reacting with a specific site of a T-cell receptor or an antibody.

A paratope (option B)is the specific site of an antibody that reacts with the corresponding epitope of an antigen.

Haptens are low molecular weight molecules that lack immunogenicity (cannot induce an immune response) themselves. They can become immunogenic by combining with a large molecule carrier. Haptens are classified as:

  • Complex haptens (option D): They contain two or more epitopes and can precipitate with specific antibodies.
  • Simple haptens (option C): They contain only one epitope. They bind to antibodies but are not precipitating.

questions.text: Method of choice to sterilize the given instrument is:
questions.solution:
Isopropyl alcohol is the method of choice to sterilize clinical thermometer.

Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery

questions.text: Monospot test is done in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Monospot test (Paul-Bunnell test) is done to identify heterophile antibody in a case of infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: Mycoplasma is inherently resistant to which of the following antibiotics?
questions.solution:
Mycoplasma are inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

Mycoplasma lack cell wall, and are therefore inherently resistant to antibiotics acting on the bacterial cell wall e.g. beta-lactams (penicillins, cephalosporins).

questions.text: Immunoblotting is a technique used in immunology also called as _______
questions.solution:
Immunoblotting, also called western blotting, is a technique used to identify a particular antigen in a complex mixture of proteins.

  • Northern blotting is a technique used to detect RNA in a sample.
  • Northwestern blotting is used to identify the interaction between the RNA and proteins.
  • Nephelometry is used to quantify a wide variety of analytes in serum or plasma such as immunoglobulins.

questions.text: A college student came to the OPD with fever and muscle aches. He tells you he had consumed smoked pork at a party 2 weeks back. Following this, he had developed abdominal cramps and diarrhea which had resolved on their own. CBC revealed eosinophilia and the muscle biopsy showed the following finding. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Abdominal cramps and diarrhea after consumption of smoked pork, followed by fever, muscle aches and eosinophilia 2 weeks later, with muscle biopsy showing encysted larvae are suggestive of trichinellosis. It is caused by Trichinella spiralis.

Trichinella spiralis, known as pork worm, is acquired by consuming raw or undercooked pork. The initial infection presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. In the later phase of the infection, the larvae migrate from the intestines into the circulation and migrate into muscles. This leads to periorbital and facial edema, splinter hemorrhages and cough. Patients also have fever,  myalgia, muscle edema and weakness. These larvae are calcified in about 5-6 months.

Blood eosinophilia develops in most patients 2-4 weeks after infection. Serum levels of creatine phosphokinase are elevated. Spiral larvae are seen in muscle biopsy. Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius, or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy.

Other parasites that can be demonstrated in a muscle biopsy are Taenia solium and Trypanosoma cruzi (amastigote).

questions.text: A patient presents with fever, arthralgia, and pain behind the eyes for 3 days. On examination, she has the following rash. Lab reports show thrombocytopenia and leucopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the symptoms and the rash suggests dengue fever.

It presents with sudden-onset fever, retro-orbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The rash in dengue appears as white islands on a red sea due to erythema with petechiae. The alternative name for dengue, breakbone fever, comes from the associated muscle and joint pains.

Suspected cases of dengue are confirmed by the presence of NS1 antigen or IgM antibodies.

The treatment of dengue is supportive with hydration taking top priority. Severe cases where there is symptomatic thrombocytopenia or a platelet count of <10000-20000 cells/cumm require platelet transfusions.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with lesions on his face as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism of this boy's condition.
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a boy presenting with small pearly white umbilicated wart-like lesions with a characteristic dimple at the center  is suggestive of infection by Molluscum contagiosum virus, which belongs to the pox virus family.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limiting viral disease of the skin caused by molluscum contagiosum virus. The age of peak incidence is between 2 and 5 years. In children, it is mainly caused by the type I molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV-1). There is a relatively higher incidence of MCV‐2 type in adults and HIV infection. Sexually transmitted molluscum contagiosum may be present over the genital area.

It has an incubation period of 2 weeks to 6 months. The lesions are shiny, pearly white, hemispherical, umbilicated papules that may show a central pore. These may enlarge slowly. Widespread and refractory lesions are seen most commonly in HIV or patients on immunosuppressive therapy. 

It is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion bodies called Henderson-Patterson bodies or molluscum bodies. Pseudo-Koebner phenomenon is seen i.e., new lesions develop along a line of trauma.

The diagnosis is usually clear when multiple lesions at different stages of evolution are seen and the classical umbilicated papule is observed. Diagnosis can be confirmed by direct microscopy, histopathology, or molecular analysis.

Treatment is usually not required, and lesions are likely to resolve spontaneously. Stimulation of the immune response can be done after destructive or inflammatory therapies with salicylic acid, trichloroacetic acid, and imiquimod. Cryotherapy when done needs to be repeated at 3-4 week intervals. Extensive lesions are treated with an antiviral agent like cidofovir.

questions.text: Which among the following is a subcutaneous fungal agent?
questions.solution: Sporothrix schenckii is a subcutaneous fungal agent. The other three mentioned are systemic mycoses.

questions.text: The pap smear shown in the image below shows infestation by:
questions.solution: The pap smear shows actinomyces appearing as balls of dark stained filamentous organisms that appear as cotton balls or woolly masses. These masses are also referred to as "Gupta Bodies" or "Dust Bunnies". Although the bacteria is generally a commensal, the actinomyces is known to cause infection in patients who have IUDs.

questions.text: Donovan bodies seen on biopsy is a characteristic feature of:
questions.solution:
Donovan bodies seen on the biopsy is characteristic of granuloma inguinale. 

Donovan bodies are seen in granuloma inguinale, which is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly Calymmatobacterium granulomatis). It presents with painless beefy red ulcers. Inguinal lymph nodes are not usually enlarged, but the infection can spread subcutaneously and give the appearance of "pseudo buboes".

The diagnosis is made by Giemsa staining, which shows the Donovan bodies. They show bipolar staining ("safety-pin appearance"). Donovan bodies appear as rounded coccobacilli within cystic spaces in large mononuclear cells.

The given image shows Intracellular Donovan bodies in Wright/Giemsa-stained impression smears:
