questions.text: Beta haemolytic streptococci are classified based on:
questions.solution:
Lancefield grouping of streptococci is based on group-specific carbohydrate antigen.

  • Beta-haemolytic streptococci were classified by Lancefield based on group-specific carbohydrate C antigen present on the cell wall, into 20 serological types from Group A to Group V except for I and J.
  • Group A beta-haemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are further classified based on protein (M, T, and R) antigens present on the cell surface by Griffith typing.

questions.text: The chromosome involved in DiGeorge syndrome is ________
questions.solution:
Chromosome 22 is involved in DiGeorge syndrome 

DiGeorge syndrome (Thymic hypoplasia) is the most common microdeletion syndrome characterized by low copy repeats and the deletion which occurs near the middle of the chromosome 22.

  • It is a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.
  • It leads to aplasia and hypoplasia of thymus and parathyroid glands.
  • It is usually associated with Fallot’s Tetralogy and other anomalies of heart. Neonatal tetany is also seen.

Image: A child with DiGeorge syndrome, showing characteristic facial appearance, with tubular nose and carp-shaped (fish-like) mouth.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of DiGeorge syndrome- Mnemonic

DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder caused by the deletion of a small segment of chromosome 22 (22q11) leading to a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches. (Thymus and parathyroid glands)

The clinical features can be remembered with the mnemonic – CATCH

  • C – Cardiac defects
  • A – Abnormal facies
  • T – Thymic aplasia
  • C – Cleft palate
  • H – Hypocalcemia

The image below shows the abnormal facies in DiGeorge syndrome.

questions.text: A 50-year-old renal transplant patient presented with difficulty in vision. The fundoscopy was done and is shown below. Which of the following is false about the pathogen causing the disease?

choices.text: It  can cause pneumonia in bone marrow transplant patients
Congenital infection can cause intrauterine growth retardation
Valganciclovir is the treatment of choice for the infection of eye
Serological assays are important for immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
The given scenario of an immunocompromised patient (post-renal transplant) presenting with difficulty in vision and the fundoscopic image showing patchy areas of retinal necrosis with irregular borders and overlying retinal hemorrhages is suggestive of Cytomegalovirus retinitis. Serological assays are not informative in immunocompromised patients as they are unable to mount a strong enough immunological reaction to be detected by the serological tests.

CMV retinitis shows “pizza pie” or “scrambled eggs and ketchup appearance” or “cottage cheese” on fundus examination. It appears as an arcuate zone of retinitis with hemorrhages and optic disc swelling. Often CMV is confined to the retinal periphery, beyond the view of the direct ophthalmoscope. Frosted branch angiitis (FBA) shows marked vascular sheathing. Cataract is a finding in the late stage of the disease.

Highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART) is the mainstay of management in the case of AIDS patients, restoring the patient’s innate ability to suppress CMV activity. Valganciclovir is taken orally and Ganciclovir is used as a slow-release intravitreal implant (Option C).

Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection in immunocompromised patients like bone marrow transplant recipients can lead to conditions like pneumonia, colitis, retinitis, or disseminated infection (Option A). Congenital infection can lead to features of intrauterine growth retardation, jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, microcephaly, and retinitis in the baby (Option B).

Screening is done in patients with low CD4 counts once in 3 months if <50/μL, once in 6 months if 50–100/μL, and once a year, if >100/μL. The PCR assay is the gold standard for diagnosis.

questions.text: Giant cell (Hecht's) pneumonia is due to?
questions.solution:
• Hecht's pneumonia, also known as giant cell pneumonia, is a fatal but rare complication of measles, which is seen in children with immunodeficiency or severe malnutrition.

The postmortem examination (autopsy) shows multinucleated giant cells lining the alveoli (air sacs) of the lungs.

questions.text: Water lily sign is seen in infection due to:
questions.solution:
The water-lily sign is seen in hydatid infections when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimic the appearance of a water lily.

It is classically described on plain radiographs (mainly chest X-ray) when the collapsed membranes are calcified but may be seen on ultrasound, CT or MRI.

questions.text: A 30 year old female developed pruritic papules with excoriated plaques in the interdigital web spaces. Later the lesion spread to the groin and under-surface of the breasts. The lady gives a history of intense pruritus which is more severe at night. Given below is the organism responsible for this condition. Identify the wrong statement about the same.

choices.text: The entire life cycle takes about 15 days
Male parasite burrows into the epidermis

questions.solution:
The clinical background is probably suggestive Scabies. The given image depicts Itch mite also called Sarcoptes scabiei. The female parasite burrows into the stratum corneum layer of the epidermis and lays eggs in the burrow.

A single female may lay about 30 eggs at a rate of 2 to 3 per day, and ultimately dies at the end of the burrow.

The life cycle has 4 stages: Egg, Larva, Nymph, and Adult. The adult mites live for 1 to 2 months.

Itching is a hypersensitivity reaction to the eggs and dead parasite in the epidermis.

Permethrin cream - 5% is the treatment of choice.

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated?
questions.solution:
Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated.

Septicemia occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream. This causes an inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis - fever, hypotension, alkalosis. 

Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections include food poisoning caused by enterotoxin, toxic shock syndrome caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin.

questions.text: As part of developing the public health policy on HIV in India, which of the following modes of transmission would you focus on the most?
questions.solution:
Heterosexual transmission is the most common mode of transmission of HIV infection in developing countries such as India and African countries. In many Western countries, male-to-male sexual transmission is the dominant mode of transmission. 

Blood transfusion carries the highest risk per 10000 exposures of getting HIV from an infected person. However, it is not the most common mode of transmission. Other modes of transmission includes a transplacental spread, however that is less common than the causes mentioned above. 

Related Pearl: Prevention of parent to child transmission (PPTCT)

Important provisions of PPTCT services for HIV:

  • HIV counseling and testing for all pregnant women enrolled in antenatal care with ‘opt out’ option.
  • Lifelong ART i.e. Tenofovir (TDF) + Lamivudine (3TC)+ Dolutegravir (DTG) administration to all pregnant and breastfeeding HIV-infected women regardless of CD4 count and clinical stage.
  • Institutional deliveries of HIV-infected mothers
  • Care of associated conditions (STI/RTI, TB, opportunistic infections, hypertension, diabetes)
  • Exclusive breastfeeding counseling
  • Plasma viral load testing at 32–36 weeks of gestation to determine the risk of HIV transmission to the baby
  • Initiation of ARV in babies:
    • Low-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine from birth till 6 weeks of age
    • High-risk infants: Syrup Nevirapine+ syrup Zidovudine either from birth till 6 weeks of age (exclusive replacement feeding) or from birth till 12 weeks of age (exclusive breastfeeding)
  • Nutrition counseling and psychosocial support to HIV-infected pregnant women
  • Ensure co-trimoxazole prophylactic therapy (CPT) and early infant diagnosis using HIV-DNA PCR at 6 weeks of age onwards as per guidelines

questions.text: Which of the following viruses belongs to the family filoviridae, and is transmitted as depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ebola virus belongs to the family filoviridae and is transmitted by bats.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Ebola virus shows a bowl of spaghetti appearance.
  • The current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: Which of the following is a type I hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease.

  • It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cyst and sterilized by Seitz filtration on the forearm and an equal volume of saline injected on the other forearm.
  • Observations are made for next 30 mins and after 1 to 2 days.
  • A wheal response occurring at the injection site within 20 minutes is considered positive.

Cell-mediated or type IV type of hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed hypersensitivity.

  • In the tuberculin skin test, the indurated skin rash is caused by CD4-positive helper T cells and macrophages that are attracted to the injection site.
  • The Frei test is done to identify lymphogranuloma venereum. Antigen made from sterile pus aspirated from previously unruptured abscesses produced a reaction in patients with lymphogranuloma inguinale when injected intradermally.
  • Montenegro test is a delayed hypersensitivity test for cutaneous leishmaniasis.

questions.text: DOC of chlamydia in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Treatment of genital Chlamydias:-

Single dose azithromycin regimen is DOC

Treatment of chlamydia in pregnancy:-

  • Although not approved by the FDA for use in pregnancy, single dose regimen of azithromycin regimen appears to be safe and effective for this purpose.
  • However, amoxicillin (500 mg three times a daily for 7 days) can also be given to pregnant women.
  • The fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy.

questions.text:
A microbiologist was studying a fungal cell wall polysaccharide called glucan, which has been used for the diagnosis of certain invasive fungal infections. Which of the following fungal infections can be detected by this assay?

1. Invasive aspergillosis
2. Invasive candidiasis
3. Invasive cryptococcosis
4. Pneumocystis jiroveci infection
questions.solution:
The given diagnostic assay is a 1, 3 beta D Glucan assay. Invasive aspergillosis, invasive candidiasis, and infection with Pneumocystis jiroveci are detected by this assay. But, invasive cryptococcosis is not detected by this assay. It is diagnosed by the detection of the cryptococcus capsular polysaccharide.

Fungi have an essential rigid cell wall that determines their shape and protects them from environmental stresses. Cell walls are made up of carbohydrate layers, glycoproteins, and lipids. It has components such as chitin, glucan, and mannans which are cross-linked to form a multilayered cell wall matrix. In addition, other polysaccharides may be unique to specific fungal species and therefore useful for identification.

1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide composed of glucose polymers and is found in most fungi, more commonly: candida, aspergillus, and Pneumocystis jiroveci.  

However, it is not detectable in the fungi such as cryptococci, zygomycetes, and Blastomyces dermatitidis, which either lack the glucan entirely or produce it at minimal levels.  

This assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) used to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed horseshoe crab (Limulus polyphemus) amebocytes. These cells contain factors C and G which are components of the Limulus clotting cascade. Factor C initiates coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and factor G initiates coagulation in the presence of Beta D Glucan. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, the manufacturers limit activation of the cascade to Beta D glucan alone.

questions.text: A patient presented with a swelling and chronic pus discharge from the mandibular region. The swelling developed a few days after undergoing a dental procedure 6 months ago. The discharge was foul-smelling with numerous yellow granules. Which of the following is false regarding the implicated pathogen?

choices.text: The causative organism is a gram-positive anaerobe
Sulfur granules are seen under microscopy
Treatment involves administration of penicillin for 2 weeks
Molar tooth colonies are seen when it is grown on brain-heart infusion agar

questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation, this is a case of cervicofacial actinomycosis caused by Actinomyces israeli. Infections caused by actinomyces should be treated by penicillin for about 6-12 months.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is an anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria. 

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It usually occurs following aspiration or trauma leading to inoculation of the infective material.
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by Gram staining of sulfur granules that shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance). Culture shows the "molar tooth" appearance of the colonies. On solid media, A. israeli produces spidery colonies. 

Treatment:

Penicillin G is the drug of choice and requires prolonged administration where the duration of therapy is between 6-12 months. The other drugs that can be used include amoxicillin, erythromycin, tetracycline, doxycycline, clindamycin, and minocycline. Surgical excision and drainage may be required.

Other options:

  • Molar tooth colonies are seen on brain-heart infusion agar.
  • Sulfur granules (unstained gross yellow color) are seen under microscopy.

Histological image showing Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon by actinomyces (eosinophilic rim at the periphery of the colony consists of immunoglobulin).

"Molar tooth" colonies shown on brain-heart infusion agar

questions.text: Penile scrapings from an immunocompromised patient show multinucleate giant cells with Lipschultz bodies. If he develops encephalitis, which of the following lobes is most commonly involved?
questions.solution:
Lipschultz bodies are intranuclear inclusion bodies seen in the multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells) in case of herpes simplex infection (HSV-1 & HSV-2). Tzanck preparation (Wright & Giemsa staining) of the tissue scrapings reveals these findings. Herpes simplex can cause encephalitis and temporal lobe is most commonly involved.

MRI showing prominent swelling, increase T2 signal involving the left temporal lobe and insular cortex.

Herpes simplex usually spreads by sexual contact or vertical transmission from the pregnant mother to the fetus. Clinical manifestations range from oral-cutaneous lesions to disseminated disease-causing encephalitis, pneumonitis, and hepatitis.

Safe sexual practice and the use of antivirals like acyclovir remain the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: Which organism shows the below-depicted phenomenon when incubated with staphylococcus aureus on blood agar?
questions.solution:
The given image shows the phenomenon of satellitism which is exhibited by Haemophilus influenzae when incubated on blood agar along with Staphylococcus aureus.

H. influenzae requires growth factors V and X that are present in the blood.

  • Factor V  is a nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD), a coenzyme, and is heat labile.
  • Factor X is hemin. It is required for cytochrome synthesis and the function of enzymes like catalase and peroxidase. It is heat stable.

Satellitism is seen when S. aureus is streaked across a plate of blood agar on which H. influenzae has been inoculated. After overnight incubation, the colonies of H. influenzae will be large and well-developed alongside the streak of Staphylococcus and smaller when they are farther away from the streak. This is due to the release of factor V by lysis of RBCs mediated by S. aureus. Thus factor V is present in high concentrations near the streak. The Hemophilus colonies become progressively smaller further away from the streak because the factor V concentration becomes less. 

The given image shows satellitism on blood agar.

questions.text: A patient following use of contact lens, developed corneal ulcers and symptoms of conjunctivitis. Saline mount preparation of corneal scrapping shows polygonal cyst. What should be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis in this case is acanthamoeba keratitis.

Acanthamoeba:

The life cycle consists of 2 stages: A trophozoite (which is 14-40 µm in diameter) and a cyst (which has a double-layered wall with a diameter of 12-16 µm). Cysts are quite resistant to environmental and chemical insults.

This genus causes 3 clinical syndromes:

  • Granulomatous amebic encephalitis (GAE)
  • Disseminated granulomatous amebic disease (eg, skin, sinus, and pulmonary infections)
  • Amebic ocular keratitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is a sight-threatening infection secondary to contamination of contact lenses. Patients with contact lenses should be warned of exposure to water containing ubiquitous Acanthamoeba cysts, especially by swimming, showering, and using homemade lens-cleaning solutions.

questions.text: Histology under KOH preparation showed the following bodies. This is seen in case of _________
questions.solution:
The image shows medlar bodies which are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Histologically on potassium hydroxide preparation, the lesions show the presence of the fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies/ medlar bodies/ copper penny bodies. These structures multiply by septation, and they induce a purulent and granulomatous inflammatory reaction in tissue.

Chromoblastomycosis is the most common form of chromomycosis, which is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi.

The M/C fungi responsible are species of the genera Fonsecaea (Fonsecaea pedrosoi or Fonsecaea compacta).

questions.text: Pertussis toxin acts by which of the following mechanism?
questions.solution:
Pertussis toxin acts by ADP-Ribosylation. It is expressed on the surface of Bordatella pertussis and is secreted into the environment.

Bordatella pertussis is a gram negative capsulated coccobacilli which causes whooping cough/pertussis (pertussis meaning intense cough)

Detection of bacilli in the upper respiratory tract by microscopy or culture confirms diagnosis. Respiratory samples can be collected by per-nasal swab, post-nasal swab or using the cough plate method. 

The Bordet-Gengou medium is used to culture the bacilli which are seen as small, dome-shaped, greyish white, refractile and glistening colonies, resembling 'bisected pearls' or 'mercury drops'. Confluent growth presents an 'aluminium paint' appearance.

 

 

Bordetella pertussis produces 3 hemagglutinins:

  • Pertussis toxin (PT)
  • FHA (Filamentous hemagglutinin)
  • Lipid factor

PT plays a major role in the pathogenesis of whooping cough. It acts by promoting lymphocytosis, increasing sensitization to histamine, and enhanced insulin secretion by means of ADP ribosylation that disrupts function of signal transduction in many cell types. FHA is responsible for facilitating the adhesion of Bordetella pertussis to the respiratory epithelium. FHA and PT also promote secondary infection by coating other bacteria such as Haemophilus influenzae and Pneumococci and assisting their binding to respiratory epithelium. This phenomenon has been termed 'piracy of adhesins'

Whooping cough is treated with erythromycin or one of the newer macrolides such azithromycin.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen, without adjuvant, intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span, with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for neurosyphilis?

choices.text: FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

questions.solution:
The investigation of choice for neurosyphilis is VDRL.

The CSF-VDRL test is highly specific and, when reactive, is considered diagnostic of neurosyphilis.

Involvement of the CNS in syphilis is detected by examination of CSF for:

  • Mononuclear pleocytosis (>5 white blood cells/μL).
  • Increased protein concentration (>45 mg/dL).
  • CSF VDRL reactivity.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: You are a microbiology resident teaching the staining technique shown in the image below to medical students. What is the order of the steps to be followed in this technique?

choices.text: Crystal violet, iodine solution, decolorisation, carbol fuchsin
Crystal violet, decolorisation, iodine solution, carbol fuchsin
Carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation, crystal violet
Crystal violet, carbol fuchsin, iodine solution, decolorisation

questions.solution:
The given microscopy image shows Gram staining, and the order of Gram staining is as follows:

  • Primary staining with para-rosaniline dye (crystal violet, methyl violet, or gentian violet)
  • Application of dilute iodine solution
  • Decolorisation with an organic solvent (ethanol, acetone, aniline)
  • Counterstaining with the dye of contrasting color (carbol fuchsin, safranine, neutral red)

The suggested theories in Gram staining are that a gram-positive organism retains the primary basic dye due to its acidic protoplasm. Also, a thick peptidoglycan layer present in gram-positive bacteria helps in retaining the dye-iodine complex. The lipid content in gram-negative bacteria is very high, which makes it permeable to secondary dye after decolorization with organic solvents like acetone.

Therefore, gram-positive bacteria retain the primary stain and appear violet. Gram-negative bacteria appear red because they get decolorized and take up the counterstain.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: A 25-year-old man came with complaints of fever and a skin lesion as shown below. He gives a history of hiking in scrub forests a week prior, where he suffered an insect bite. On examination, there is regional lymphadenopathy and a maculopapular rash. Which of the following arthropods is involved in the spread of this disease?
questions.solution:
A history of contact with scrub vegetation with fever, regional lymphadenopathy, maculopapular rash, and eschar at the bite site is suggestive of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and transmitted by trombiculid mite. Doxycycline 100mg BD for 7-14 days is the drug of choice for treatment of scrub typhus in adults. In case of pregnant women and children, azithromycin or chloramphenicol may be preferred where doxycycline is relatively contraindicated.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given above depicts the mechanism of action of botulinum toxin.

It causes proteolysis of snare proteins. Snare proteins have three components- synaptobrevin, SNAP25 and syntaxin. The snare protein is required for the excocytosis of acetylcholine vesicles. Thus it leads to presynaptic inhibition of neuronal transmission.

There are 7 different strains of clostridium botulinum and each strain acts by a different mechanism. Toxins of C. Botulinum A, C and E cleave SNAP25. Type C also cleaves syntaxin. Type B, D, F and G cleave synaptobrevin.
